It doesn't take 12 billion years for a galaxy to form, yet in reality, we have observed galaxies less than a billion year old. Their relative age is exactly the duration that their light has reached Earth. If its light has reached Earth for 500 million years, the galaxy's age to us is 500 million year old. Know that, their age is not 500 million years old everywhere universally. The galaxies next to that 500m yold galaxy will see its age around 13 billion years. To them, our galaxy is 500 million years old. They're seeing our galaxy when it's that young. We're living in 12 billion years into their future, if thinking in absolute time. The reason we've settled with this relativistic time/age is because we've settled that nothing can travel faster light. A 13 billion years old galaxy over there doesn't mean anything to us, because we can never reach it instantly.
